title: 110_hr3519
content: The Act is titled the "United States Commission on an Open Society with Security Act." Congress finds that an open society with free access to public spaces and open discussion is crucial for American democratic values. The United States faces a unique challenge to public safety, requiring the assembly of experts to secure public safety from terrorist attacks while preserving democratic principles. The United States must secure public safety from terrorist attacks while ensuring free and open access to the public. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. The United States Commission on an Open Society with Security is established with 21 members appointed by the President from various fields. The Chairperson is designated by the President, and members serve for the life of the Commission. A quorum of nine members is required for meetings. The Commission on an Open Society with Security requires a quorum of nine members for meetings. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members should be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and if 9 or more members are appointed, the Chairperson can start operations, including hiring staff. The Commission on an Open Society with Security requires a quorum of nine members for meetings. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members should be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and if 9 or more members are appointed, the Chairperson can start operations, including hiring staff. The functions of the Commission are outlined in Section 4. The Commission will study and make recommendations on balancing security and public access to Federal buildings and sites. It will specifically examine security practices, building design, public space management, counterterrorism needs, and the impact of public access on security and free speech. The Commission will study security practices, building design, public space management, counterterrorism needs, and the impact of public access on security, free speech, economies, physical changes, traffic, job performance, technology use, comparisons with other entities, and analytical methods for assessing terrorism risks. The Commission will coordinate activities to avoid duplication of efforts by others. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission, its members, and agents have the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and receive information to carry out the Act. They can obtain necessary information from US government entities. Commission members and staff must have security clearances for access to classified materials. The Commission and its staff must have security clearances and follow security protocols to access classified records and materials from government agencies. Members of the Commission and its staff must have security clearances and follow protocols to access classified records. They are restricted from using acquired information for nonofficial purposes and must have a need to know for accessing such records. The Commission may use the United States mails, accept gifts, and receive administrative support services on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will not receive compensation for their service. They will be reimbursed for travel expenses at authorized rates. The Chairperson has the authority to appoint staff without following certain regulations. The Commission can appoint a director and necessary personnel, with pay not exceeding GS-15 rates. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Chairperson can hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding GS-15 pay. The Commission will submit a final report to the President within 2 years of its initial meeting, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The President must then transmit the report to Congress within 6 months, along with any comments or proposed legislation. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its final report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2010.
